results.title: What We Do in the Shadows
results.headline_credit: New Zealand and United States of America, 2014
results.brief_description: Vampire housemates try to cope with the complexities of modern life and show a newly turned hipster some of the perks of being undead.

constellations_other.name: Spooky shadows
constellations_other.description: Hellish and hilarious vampires connect pioneering German cinema to contemporary New Zealand comedy with a quick detour into small town strangeness.

results.title: What we do at kindergarten
results.creator_credit: Pamela Eagles, Donn Clauscen, Dianne Milwright and Myles-Milwright Productions
results.brief_description: Shows daily activities in kindergartens emphasising the extent activities aid the preschool child’s development. Suitable for use with parents of kindergarten age children and for infant primary teachers as a background knowledge of what happens in kindergartens.

results.title: What to eat
results.creator_credit: Gerard Bryant, Terry Trench and Derek Stewart Productions
results.brief_description: An outline of the basic principles of nutrition. Diagrams and live action describe the nutritional value of various foods and the requirements of the body for a balanced diet of calories and vitamins. The wide choice of consumer hoods available in Britain today permits a sensible diet for all.

results.title: What to do with a dollar
results.brief_description: The State Savings Bank is closely linked with the development of Victoria. It seeks to use the dollars at its disposal for the maximum benefit of the people of Victoria. Through loan money it helps provide power, water suppl7, roads, port facilities, housing loans and rural loans.

results.title: What to do when I'm dead
results.brief_description: Beginning from the initial reactions of doubt and confusion, then moving on to remembrance, this short program follows the experiences of a brother and sister as they deal with the death of their mother who leaves them the document - “what to do when I’m dead”. The proceedings of the final day are followed as family and friends gather from near and far to share their pain. The video explores issues such as dying and funeral ceremonies at home, grieving with minimal intervention, different reactions to grief and how ‘outsiders’ affect family dynamics. Cast includes Jennifer Kent, Josh Quong Tart, Shane Porteous and Celia Ireland.

results.title: What time is it in Tokyo?
results.brief_description: Uses the principles relating to the rotation of the earth and its position in relation to the sun to explain why there are time differences around the world and how these effect us.

results.title: What the hell's going on up there?
results.creator_credit: Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A disgruntled Uncle Sam complains that nobody listens to him anymore, and what’s more, he doesn’t even know what’s going on up there. “I thought we were living on the top floor,” he mutters. He expedites the ubiquitous Marshall Efron on a fact-finding mission north of the border. Part satire, part serious, this film sets out to package Canada for American consumption, with some of the cliches thrown in. Contrasting with the decidedly lighter side of the film are interviews with well-known Canadians such as Marshall McLuhan, Mordecai Richler, Margaret Atwood, John Kenneth Galbraith, Raoul Duguay, and Pierre Bourgault.

results.title: What the Butler Saw
results.brief_description: What the Butler Saw was a mutoscope reel, and an early example of erotic films dating from the early 1900s. It depicted a scene of a woman partially undressing in her bedroom, as if some voyeuristic “butler” was watching her through a keyhole. The film was seen by depositing a coin in a freestanding viewing machine, which then freed a hand-crank on the side which was turned by the viewer. Social standards are subject to change, and by the 1950s this and similar films were considered harmless when compared to contemporary erotica. - Wikipedia

results.title: What teacher expects...the self fulfilling prophecy (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Cristin Weingartner, Barrie Angus McLean, Dorothy Courtois, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film presenting a provocative theory of interest to educators and parents: that a child’s performance in school is often closely related to what his teacher expects of him, rather than what an intelligence test might indicate him capable of. Dr. Robert Rosenthal of Harvard University and Dr. Sam Rabinovitch of McGill University and the Montreal Children’s Hospital discuss this little-recognised inter-reaction. This theory is demonstrated in teacher-pupil situations where the subject is word-recognition.
